columns.text: In this problem, we will solve for the net present value of the project.

Before we get to solve the net present value, we must first solve for the necessary information. First off, we will solve for the sales. To do this, we will simply multiply the number of units sold by the price.

For **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Sales}&=5,100 \times \$425\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,167,500
\end{aligned}$$

The sales for Year 1 is $\$2,167,500$

For **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Sales}&=5,800 \times \$425\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,465,000
\end{aligned}$$

The sales for Year 2 is $\$2,465,000$

For **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Sales}&=6,400 \times \$425\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,720,000
\end{aligned}$$

The sales for Year 3 is $\$2,720,000$

For **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Sales}&=4,700 \times \$425\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,997,500
\end{aligned}$$

The sales for Year 4 is $\$1,997,500$

Now that we have the revenue, we can solve for the variable costs which amount to $15\%$ of the sales. This can be done by simply multiplying the sales by $0.15$

For **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable cost}&=\$2,167,500 \times 0.15\\[15 pt]
&=\$325,125
\end{aligned}$$

The variable cost for Year 1 is $\$325,125$

For **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable cost}&=\$2,465,000 \times 0.15\\[15 pt]
&=\$369,750
\end{aligned}$$

The variable cost for Year 2 is $\$369,750$

For **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable cost}&=\$2,720,000 \times 0.15\\[15 pt]
&=\$408,000
\end{aligned}$$

The variable cost for Year 3 is $\$408,000$

For **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable cost}&=\$1,997,500 \times 0.15\\[15 pt]
&=\$299,625
\end{aligned}$$

The variable cost for Year 4 is $\$299,625$

Next, we will solve for the depreciation. In this case, we will use the Modified Accelerated Cash Recovery System method where a fixed rate will be multiplied to the initial investment per year. For this, we will use a three-year MACRS computation which will give us the following rates:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Year 1}&=0.3333\\
\text{Year 2}&=0.4445\\
\text{Year 3}&=0.1481\\
\text{Year 4}&=0.0741
\end{aligned}$$

To solve for the depreciation, simply multiply the initial investment by the given factor in Step 11.

For **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$2,650,000 \times 0.3333\\[15 pt]
&=\$883,245
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation for Year 1 is $\$883,245$

For **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$2,650,000 \times 0.4445\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,177,925
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation for Year 2 is $\$1,177,925$

For **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$2,650,000 \times 0.1481\\[15 pt]
&=\$392,465
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation for Year 3 is $\$392,465$

For **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$2,650,000 \times 0.0741\\[15 pt]
&=\$196,365
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation for Year 4 is $\$196,365$

Next that we will do is to solve for the earnings before interest and tax which is basically the sales subtracted by the fixed cost, variable cost, and the depreciation. 

For **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Earnings before interest and tax}&=\$2,167,500 -\$345,000\\
&-\$325,125-\$883,245\\[15 pt]
&=\$614,130
\end{aligned}$$

The earnings before interest and tax for Year 1 is $\$614,130$

For **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Earnings before interest and tax}&=\$2,465,000 -\$345,000\\
&-\$369,750-\$1,177,925\\[15 pt]
&=\$572,325
\end{aligned}$$

The earnings before interest and tax for Year 2 is $\$572,325$

For **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Earnings before interest and tax}&=\$2,720,000 -\$345,000\\
&-\$408,000-\$392,465\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,574,535
\end{aligned}$$

The earnings before interest and tax for Year 3 is $\$1,574,535$

For **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Earnings before interest and tax}&=\$1,997,500 -\$345,000\\
&-\$299,625-\$196,365\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,156,510
\end{aligned}$$

The earnings before interest and tax for Year 4 is $\$1,156,510$

Next, we will solve for the net income by taking the earnings before interest and tax and multiplying it to one minus the tax rate.

For **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net income}&=\$614,130 \times (1-0.22)\\[15 pt]
&=\$479,021.40
\end{aligned}$$

The net income for Year 1 is $\$479,021.40$

For **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net income}&=\$572,325 \times (1-0.22)\\[15 pt]
&=\$446,413.50
\end{aligned}$$

The net income for Year 2 is $\$446,413.50$

For **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net income}&=\$1,574,535 \times (1-0.22)\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,228,137.30
\end{aligned}$$

The net income for Year 3 is $\$1,228,137.30$

For **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net income}&=\$1,156,510 \times (1-0.22)\\[15 pt]
&=\$902,077.80
\end{aligned}$$

The net income for Year 4 is $\$902,077.80$

To solve for the cash flow, we will use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cashflow}&=\text{Net income}+(\text{Depreciation} \times \text{Tax})
\end{aligned}$$

For the operating cash flow of **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow}&=\$479,021.40+(\$883,245\times 0.22)\\[15 pt]
&=\$673,335.30
\end{aligned}$$

The operating cash flow for Year 1 is $\$673,335.30$

For the operating cash flow of **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow}&=\$446,413.50+(\$1,177,925\times 0.22)\\[15 pt]
&=\$705,557
\end{aligned}$$

The operating cash flow for Year 2 is $\$705,557$

For the operating cash flow of **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow}&=\$1,228,137.30+(\$392,465\times 0.22)\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,314,479.60
\end{aligned}$$

The operating cash flow for Year 3 is $\$1,314,479.60$

For the operating cash flow of **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow}&=\$902,077.80+(\$196,365\times 0.22)\\[15 pt]
&=\$945,278.10
\end{aligned}$$

The operating cash flow for Year 4 is $\$945,278.10$

Now that we have the net income for the four years, we will solve for the initial cashflow. To do this, we will simply add the amount used for the initial investment, the land, and the net working capital.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Initial cashflow}&=\$2,650,000 +\$2,100,000+\$125,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,490,000
\end{aligned}$$

Since these are all outgoing, we will get the negative value of this, Thus, the initial cash flow is $-\$2,490,000$

Since we already have the cash flows, we can solve for the net present value using the formula in Step 2:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value}&=\dfrac{\$673,335.30}{(1+0.13)^1}+\dfrac{\$705,557}{(1+0.13)^2}\\
&+\dfrac{\$1,314,479.60}{(1+0.13)^3}+\dfrac{\$945,278.10}{(1+0.13)^4}\\
&-\$2,490,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$149,183.63
\end{aligned}$$

The net present value of this project is $\$149,183.63$
